div.p: At first I was tempted to start a philosophical debate about RPG rules in general and a justification of my attempt specifically. But this would soon turn out to take up more space than the entire rules to be presented. So this discussion must be provided elsewhere. Suffice it to say that my disinfatuation with current rules available stems from the fact that they are overly complicated for the little "fitness" they show for representing the genre or game world they supposedly apply to.
Two major issues that annoy in particular I want to address shortly in the next two section.

One of the technical flaws of almost every single set of rules I have come across is the applicability of skills and difficulties as they progress. With this rule set, higher skill levels compare to higher difficulty level exactly as lower skills and lower difficulty level. At every level the rules yield the same probability.

One consequence of this, as it turns out, is that using rules for multiple actors or multiple targets happens (scales) smoothly. There are no odd jumps in probabilities when rules are applied to groups nor is there a need for a new type of rule. Thus separate rules that apply to massive or complex (large scale) situations are not necessary.

Many rule sets complicate situations, especially combat, because they address the complexity of tactical decisions by creating artificial dimensions. Strength, Combat skills and Hit points are the dominating techical terms. This unnecessary creation of dimensions should be avoided. Tactical decisions should only be applied to comprehensive dimensions, which directly relate to the reality modelled. This is done here in the hope that both simplicity and realism can be fostered at the same time.

You roll a until you roll a and the count the number of dice that did not show up a . That is the same as the number of dice you actually rolled minus one. The higher you get, the better, therefore we call it the positive roll. This roll is dominated by the active character, or more generally, the actor. Of course, there is a negative roll that is associated with the passive resistance or impediment, which is handled in the same way. These two numbers are subtracted. The result will be a whole number (i.e. a positive or negative number without fractional part). An understanding of this rule is crucial, so we elaborate a bit by listing the probabilities involved as well as some examples.

The first row shows the result achieved when you roll. The second row shows the chance that you have of moving up one point (i.e. left) at any given point. Note that this chance is always the same. Then third row gives the percentage chance that you have of achieving the result in the corresponding first row. These you could achieve by rolling a in order to cut down on the number of dice to roll. All but the first column of this row are approximations.

The last column is somewhat special. It combines all higher results. You could expand the table to infinity, if you wanted. While the extensions of the first and second row are quite obvious, the third is not. It should be interpreted thus: if you roll 91-100, you need to roll again on this table, get the result as before and then add 10 to the result. (For the mathematically inclined, this is a recursive definition, since it is possible that you roll 91-100 again, which forces you to roll on this table again and add 20 to the net result from the repeated application. We will see this in the examples.)

The previous table only considered one roll, the positive or the negative roll. (You can also call them the active and the passive roll; in most instances the obstacle is passive, such as door being lock-picked or a weight being lifted.) The following table shows the chances for overall results. Generally, this table is interpreted as the one above, with a few key differences.

With a roll of 01-06 and 95-100 the extended roll is continued on the previous table with the obvious consequences. Positive continuation is correct, while negative continuation results in negative results to be added. The second row cell below the 0 result means 4/9 chance to increase the result by 1, the same chance to descrease the result by one and a 1/9 to stay at 0. The astute reader will see the chance for 0 in the third row is only 8%, while 1/9 ~ 11%. Again this is due to rounding; the price for rolling less dice.

In order to keep the probabilities correct, all rolls should be made in secret and the result only be exposed when necessary. In many situtations this is highly impractical, you therefore need to decide, when to sacrifice correctness for playability. We will see in later sections examples of this. But it should be obvious that a player will rather break of a long lasting activity when he knows it will not end well. Think of a race, where everyone knows the probable outcome after a few meters have been run.
In case a more precise outcome needs to be rolled, roll a for as many digits after the decimal point as needed.

The most generic way to roll the dice would be to roll until a is rolled. To improve speed, several may be rolled in ordered fashion. Order them according to size or alphabetical color (e.g. black, blue, green, yellow) or in any other way you can remember. With a stop at or . If you lack s, you can also roll s with only a marginal 3% error on each roll. But all players (and GM) should roll the same type dice. Computer applications that make rolling as easy as pressing a button are also easy to program.

div.p:
This basic rule has several advantages over other rules that are proposed in other systems. In no particular order:
Active and passive are symmetrical. If you imagine one character stealthily evading another, the first may interprete the rolls as his actively evading against a passive observation of the surroundings, while the second may interprete the rolls as his actively scrutinzing the vicinity against a passively hiding opponent. Either way, one roll (or set of rolls) will determine the outcome.
Scaling with respect to difficulty. Imagine that one character is particularly strong with a certain skill, but he also attempts more difficult tasks. Imagine the child character climbing the neighborhood tree and as a grown, experienced man climbing an overhanging cliff. The child's climbing bonus of 12 against a difficulty addition of 14 for the tree gives the same distribution as the adult's bonus of 57 against the cliff's 59. (We have not made any rules on skills and difficulties yet, but the will turn out to be additions and subtractions from the levels.)

When designing the concrete implementations of skills, difficulties, situations, etc. keep in mind one of the key probability of the basic rule. And that is a result of 10 or higher has appoximately a 5% chance. For a positive/active roll alone this is at about 10%. So when designing additions/subtractions consider that when comparing numbers directly, say skills in a duel, a will only break even (or win) against a in 5% of all cases.
In the upcoming paragraphs, we will use this to create a level system. Assuming a level for every 10 point difference gives a good scale. Passing a level of higher is not impossible but improbable.

Skills (or Attributes, etc.) should be designed as to properly apply to genre-typical situations and tests. Whether generic skills and attributes or stylized, specific skills are used, depends on the genre. Such specialized application is not of importance at this stage.
The following sections deal with application of the previously explained basic rule. Many situations can be ruled according to the same principles, regardless of the specific genre-rule.

Skill tests may succeed completely, partially, or not at all. It may take more or less time to complete a task. Actions or tasks are therefore split into several appropriate dimensions, such that an action can succeed or fail in each dimension separately. The sense of introducing dimensions into the rules is to give tactical control to the actor/character. Sometimes a wall needs to be torn down, no matter how long it takes. Sometimes only a certain amount of digging can be done before it is interrupted. A very important choice is that of the right dimensions. A predominate dimension applicable to many tasks is time.

You should always try to create scalable dimensions and this is generally not hard. Time, distance, and weight are classic examples of such dimensions, But also skills such as knowledge can be made scalable.

Once you have decided on some effects for a scalable dimension, you will have a list like skill 0: 1 minute, skill 10: 2 minutes, .... The skill level will be in steps of 10 (remember the design guidelines), while the values depend on the dimension and the concrete skill. The above may be a skill of Holding Breath, but for a skill called Ten-Second-Dash the list may look like skill 0: 30 meters, skill 40: 100 meters. To have the appropriate intermediate steps, both in skill level and dimension, use the following table. On the far left and right side you will find the typical values for skill level n and n+10 in inceasing fashion. By reading from righht to left you can easily accommodate for descreasing values. Use the next to lowest row for that.

Finally, this is a utility table. Often, the instinctive linear interpolation - dividing the difference into equal steps and taking the appropriate step - is not to far from the smoother version the table gives you.

The numbers in the table have been rounded. If you want to expand the table for other differences or mitigate rounding errors and you are willing to go through the mathematics of it, the formula in the last row can be used. (The variable α being the left and β the right end.)
The following rule only applies when you deem it prudent. It combines several actors into one and that only makes sense, if resolving the situation takes less time than rolling them individually.

Sometimes several people (or more generally actors) will want to join forces to expedite an action. Jointly lifting a weight or looking for a clue are typical examples. This should be simulated by combining the joining people into one actor with an increased bonus to the activities. The same is true for attempting several tasks in one activity, where rolling many dice would become combersome. Attempting to clear away rubble instead of individual stones and broken items could be such a situation.

First decide what the bonus would be, if two characters with the same skill level combine their effort into one. Then the following table provides a way to combine two general actors into one. Take the difference in bonus (skill level) as column index and the bonus an equal skill should give as row index. Cross-indexing gives the bonus, the actor with the higher skill level should receive.

For example, assume the bonus would be a full for equal characters, but the better character is points ahead on the skill. Then this table gives the skill of the better character plus to the combined actor.

The standard example of taking the best skill roll of two (this is the same as requiring at least one of the two to succeed.) would best equate to using row in the table. If you have two actors that both must succeed a test, then you should use -, which is equivalent to using the fifth row for the reverse roll. Keep in mind that the reversal of positive and negative roll, also changes who of the two has the higher skill level.

The rule can be applied multiple times and its application does not depend on the order or sub-grouping of several actors, thereby adhering to the outline given in the motivational section. In order to keep this rule simple, the results were rounded. Using the rule multiple times, always group two actors of similar skill value together.

As a more elaborate example, say you have four characters in a room searching for something and you have determined that this technically means that either of those characters could find it, i.e. all would have to roll against a set diffculty. But you want just one roll. These characters have a skill level of , , 13, and 17. Taking the first two, because they are closest to each other, we combine them into an actor with . (The difference between the two is and from the above we know that we should use row five. We add the we find to the higher .) Now we combine and 13 in the same manner to 17. In the last step, we combine the two 17s into a 22 by way of the zero'th column.

If you want to expand the table for higher differences or mitigate rounding errors for repeated applications and you are willing to go through the mathematics of it, the formula in the last row can be used. (The variable α being the row index and β the column index.)

The variance in outcome of an activity can be controlled by manipulating the scale of a dimension. By reducing an active roll by n, the active roll can be repeated n times and the average of all (n+1</em) rolls is taken. This will result in a higher probability of the (new) average.

When actions are not completed, but aborted prematurly, partial outcomes are possible. This is usually a an interruption during the time dimension, e.g. due to inflicted wounds on an active person at some point. Consider this the equivalent of a control. That is, if the abort happens, when time to completion is n, then proceed as if the active roll had been reduced by n.

The calculations result in a level difference between the active and the passive part, which is the only number relevant for rolling. If only the failure or success is of interest and not the circumstances in the domains, you can apply the following shortcut. Since the difference must be met by the lower contestant, you may roll all the difference dice in one combined “throw” and check, whether any stop digit appears. If it does the lower contestant cannot win, since it is irrelevant, where the stop digit appears. If the stop digit does not appear, chances have reduced to 50/50, and you can flip a coin in any of a number of ways.

For example, suppose the active climber with a skill level of 57 wants to scale a cliff of difficulty 49. The difference is . The GM rolls dice, which show up , , , , , , , and . Since is a stop digit, the cliff is scaled. If the had been a , for instance, the cliff would have had a “fighting chance” to drop the character. The GM decides that even is good for the character and odd is bad and rolls a . It comes up a and the character has barely made it. Any story-telling description of this close encounter is at your option.
